bestBHT.bht: The soul, not in a selfish sense, but as one's true identity, must be preserved by hating one's life for the sake of God's will. Loving one's life too much leads to losing it, while embracing self-renunciation and staying true to Christ keeps it for eternal life. As exemplified by Jesus, the key to guarding and preserving life lies in choosing the path of self-sacrifice and remaining faithful to the teachings of Christ.

Henry Alford: The word soul (or, life, but here better, soul) is not really in a double sense: as the wheat-corn retains its identity, though it die, so the soul: so that the two senses are, in their depth, but one."
Notice, that the soul involves the life in both cases, and must not be taken in the present acceptation of that term.
But the saying here proclaims more plainly its true extent,—by its immediate connexion with ver, 24 and by the words, unto life eternal.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: He that loveth his life shall lose it; and he that hateth his life in this world shall keep it unto life eternal.

Did our Lord mean to exclude Himself from the operation of the great principle here expressed—self-renunciation, the law of self-preservation; and its converse, self-preservation, the law of self-destruction?

As He became Man to exemplify this fundamental law of the Kingdom of God in its most sublime form, so the very utterance of it on this occasion served to sustain His own Spirit in the double prospect to which He had just alluded.
Albert Barnes: He that loveth his life ... - This was a favorite principle, a sort of “axiom” with the Lord Jesus.
See the Matthew 10:39 note; Luke 9:24 note.
Marvin Vincent: Shall lose [απολεσει]. The best texts read ajpolluei, loseth. See on Luke 9:25.
John Calvin: He who, despising life, advances courageously to death, is said to hate life.
For the true limit of loving life, is, when we continue in it as long as it pleases God, and when we are prepared to leave it as soon as he shall order us.
Whoever carries his attachment to the present life beyond this limit, destroys his life; that is, he consigns it to everlasting ruin.
Philip Schaff: He that loveth his soul loseth it; and he that hateth his soul in this world shall keep it unto life eternal.
Soul is here the personality, the self, in man: yet not the self in the sense of selfishness, for selfishness must be destroyed not 'kept.'
By simply living for himself and without thought of others, he 'loses' that very thing which he desires to preserve and make happy.
Archibald T. Robertson: Clearly μισεω means 'hate' when the issue is between Christ and the dearest things of life as happens when the choice is between martyrdom and apostasy."
In that case one keeps his soul for eternal life by losing his life (ψυχη, each time) here.
That is the way to 'guard' (φυλαξε) life by being true to Christ.
John Gill: Whoever is so in love with this present temporal life...rather than to expose it to any danger, chooses to deny the faith of Christ, and desert his cause and interest; as such an one shall not long enjoy this life, so he shall come short of an eternal one.
Whoever seems careless about it, and not to consult the safety of it, but is unconcerned about it; yea, as if he was throwing it away...he shall keep it unto life eternal.

They must suffer and die, as well as he, though not on the same account, and for the self-same reasons; and that their sufferings and death in his cause, and for his Gospel, would turn to their advantage.
John Wesley: He that loveth his life — More than the will of God; shall lose it eternally: and he that hateth his life - In comparison of the will of God, shall preserve it. Matthew 10:39.

bhtAttempts.bht: The verse speaks of the importance of self-renunciation and the choice between preserving one's soul or losing it. The soul here refers to the self, not in a selfish sense, but in the sense of preserving one's true identity in relation to God. By loving one's life too much and living solely for oneself, one ironically loses the very thing they seek to protect. On the other hand, by hating one's life in comparison to the will of God, one keeps their soul for eternal life. This principle was exemplified by Jesus himself, who embraced self-renunciation even unto death. Thus, the key to guarding and preserving one's life lies in staying true to Christ and his teachings.

The soul, representing one's true self, must be preserved by hating one's life in comparison to God's will. By loving and living solely for oneself, one ironically loses what they seek to protect. Jesus exemplified self-renunciation, embracing it even unto death. Therefore, the key to guarding and preserving one's life lies in staying true to Christ and his teachings.

The soul, or life, retains its identity even in death. The soul involves life and must not be taken in the present sense. Loving one's life too much leads to losing it, while hating one's life in comparison to God's will preserves it for eternal life. Jesus exemplifies self-renunciation, sustaining his own spirit, and keeping life by being true to Christ. Therefore, the key to guarding and preserving life is staying true to Christ and embracing self-renunciation.

The soul, not in a selfish sense, but as one's true identity, must be preserved by hating one's life for the sake of God's will. Loving one's life too much leads to losing it, while embracing self-renunciation and staying true to Christ keeps it for eternal life. As exemplified by Jesus, the key to guarding and preserving life lies in choosing the path of self-sacrifice and remaining faithful to the teachings of Christ.

The soul, representing one's true self, must be preserved by hating one's life in comparison to God's will. By loving one's life too much, one ironically loses what they seek to protect. On the other hand, by embracing self-renunciation and staying true to Christ, one keeps their soul for eternal life. Jesus exemplified this principle, sustaining His spirit with the prospect of self-renunciation. Therefore, to guard and preserve life, one must choose the path of self-sacrifice and remain faithful to Christ's teachings.
